The complete piano score can be downloaded from my Portfolio, where you can also find my YouTube performance video!
Bell is a short piano piece in ternary form (Aâ€“Bâ€“Aâ€™), developed from the first eight measures that came to me rather spontaneously.
Background One day while improvising, I played the opening eight measures by chance and thought they sounded nice. I recorded them on my Yamaha P525, planning to leave the idea for later. But the melody kept looping in my mindâ€”I just couldnâ€™t stop hearing it. So I decided to finish the piece over the next few days.
The title Bell came naturally: during composition, I realized the melody carried a kind of â€œbell-likeâ€ resonance, so I named it accordingly.
On Composition Section A (mm. 1â€“22) Most of section A was born directly from improvisation on the piano.
mm. 17â€“20: The melody in measures 17â€“18 is a variation of the opening measure, reminding listeners of the pieceâ€™s main motif. Measures 19â€“20 imitate the previous two measures but shift the register to create an echoing bell effect. Section B (mm. 23â€“54) Section B mainly develops materials from section A.
mm. 23â€“26: Here, the main melody is transferred to the left handâ€”an inversion of the first four measures from section A. The right-hand line, meanwhile, augments the same material, slightly adjusting pitch direction to lead the musical flow. mm. 27â€“30: This passage mirrors measures 9â€“12 from section A. To be honest, this part (measures 23â€“30) didnâ€™t exist at firstâ€”section B originally began at measure 31. Later, I felt the piece needed more buildup before reaching the climax, so I added this transition. To make it more engaging, I deliberately varied the melodic contour and chord progression to create more contrast and dialogue. I ended up liking how it turned out.
mm. 39â€“42: This short passage connects the previous part to the coming climax. mm. 43â€“47: Here comes the climax. Initially, I tried to mirror the left hand of measures 1â€“4 in the right hand, but it didnâ€™t quite work. So I reimagined the right-hand melody by harmonizing directly from the left-hand notesâ€”and that became the core of this passage. mm. 49â€“54: To create a bell-like resonance, I wrote the left hand to play an octave on the first beat, then immediately leap to the higher register for the remaining beats. Itâ€™s a bit tricky to play but produces a shimmering echo effect. Section Aâ€™ (mm. 55â€“74) Since I loved the sound of the first eight measures so much, I wanted to bring them backâ€”so I structured the piece as Aâ€“Bâ€“Aâ€™. That way, listeners can revisit the opening melody one more time.
mm. 63â€“70: The right hand repeats the same melody from the beginning, but I changed the left-hand accompaniment for more harmonic tension. Instead of the original root-position A-flat arpeggio, I used a second inversion to evoke a sense of â€œthe music coming to an end.â€
In classical harmony, itâ€™s common to hear the cadential progression $\mathrm{I}^6_4 \rightarrow \mathrm{V}^7 \rightarrow \mathrm{I}$ near the conclusion, and I borrowed that pattern for this part. On Performance This section isnâ€™t meant to prescribe how the piece should be playedâ€”just sharing what I think sounds nice. Feel free to explore your own interpretation and to email me your thoughts!
Pedaling The pedal plays a key role in this piece. I didnâ€™t mark every pedal symbol on the score. That would make it too cluttered. And of course, I fully welcome performers to interpret pedaling differently.
One spot worth mentioning is measure 16, where I hold the pedal through the Eâ™­ on the second beat and only change it at measure 19. This creates a bell-like resonanceâ€”two tones overlapping and shimmering together, much like how real bells ring in the air. (The same applies at measure 70 in the bass note.)
For measures 23â€“26, I intentionally avoid using pedal so the section feels clean and distinct from what came before.
Tone Color This piece was originally written for the piano, but I later discovered that the â€œStage E. Pianoâ€ sound on my Yamaha P525 fits this piece beautifullyâ€”it almost feels like background music from a game. I recorded a new version with that tone and loved the result.
I also think it might sound lovely on a glockenspiel or other bell-like instruments. If you find another sound that suits the piece, Iâ€™d love to hear about it!
Conclusion Before writing this post, I asked ChatGPT for topic suggestions related to composition. It not only gave me topics but also some hilariously overly poetic lines. Here are a few:
â€œSometimes I get stuck between two notesâ€”itâ€™s like words on the tip of my tongue that I canâ€™t say.â€ $\rightarrow$ I mean, yes, I do get stuckâ€”but that metaphor is a bit too much. â€œWhen I played the final note, I suddenly felt the piece no longer belonged to me.â€ $\rightarrow$ Nope. It still does! My nameâ€™s right there on the copyright page. â€œEvery composition is a letter to a moment in time.â€ $\rightarrow$ Wow, thatâ€™s… dramatic. Sounds like something out of a romance novel. So instead of following ChatGPTâ€™s flowery advice, I decided to just write plainlyâ€”honestly recording my thoughts during the creative process.
If youâ€™ve performed this piece, Iâ€™d love to hear your version! And if you upload it anywhere, feel free to share this post with your listeners so they can get a glimpse into the story behind Bell.

The following post was originally published on Medium on April 5, 2019. Six years later, I not only deleted the apps but also permanently deleted my Instagram account, and I often keep my Facebook account deactivated. Looking back now, I truly feel that my past self had taken an excellent first step.
I joined Facebook in 2009 and have been using it for almost ten years now.
Over the years, the changes have been dramatic. It started with just a few friends playing Happy Farm together, but soon exploded into over 400 friends (I know itâ€™s still considered â€œfewâ€ by some people) flooding my feed. Not only my elementary school teachers, but even distant relatives and aunts I barely knew started adding me as a Facebook friend. My friend list became a strange mix of familiar yet unfamiliar people, and before long, I turned into a lurker, quietly scrolling through everyoneâ€™s updates.
When posting on Facebook became too full of worries and self-consciousness, I shifted my focus to Instagram, where I created a small space of freedom to write. Sometimes, after viewing someoneâ€™s story, Iâ€™d respond with a heart-eyes emojiâ€”just let them know I cared.
Yet, I found myself becoming more and more unhappy.
I would often think, â€œThat post was actually pretty good. Why didnâ€™t he/she like it?â€ Or when I was tired from writing assignments and wanted to relax by browsing social media, Iâ€™d see a classmate from the same course posting a big update celebrating that theyâ€™d finished theirs, which made me more anxious.
Moreover, I also came to realize that the people who truly matter in my lifeâ€”family, close friends, mentorsâ€”are barely active on social media at all. My most precious memories with them donâ€™t come from likes on a post, but from real moments: laughing together in sync, or being hugged and comforted when I was sad, safe enough to cry in their arms.
It wasnâ€™t until yesterday that I fully realized this. I made up my mind and posted on both Facebook and Instagram, announcing Iâ€™d disappear from the platforms for a month. I would still keep Messenger and Line, but turn off phone notifications. That way, I wouldnâ€™t be â€œon-callâ€ all the time; instead, Iâ€™d check messages and reply only once a day.
Then, I carried out the following steps in one go:
Step 1: Remove temptation. I deleted the Facebook and Instagram apps from my phone.
Step 2: Block access. I installed the â€œBlock Siteâ€ extension on Chrome and added Facebook and Instagram to the block list.
Step 3: Find alternative entertainment. Whenever I felt the urge to check social media, I redirected my attention to more productive activities, like coloring for relaxation, listening to music, reading, or writing.
Step 4: Seek support. I asked friends from church to pray for me, and I talked with family and mentors, who praised and encouraged meâ€”boosting my confidence.
I originally thought Iâ€™d need sheer willpower to resist, but to my surprise, it felt much easier than expected. After just one day, I noticed some significant changes:
My mood felt lighter. No more waiting for â€œwho hasnâ€™t liked my post yetâ€ and no more compulsive urge to clear red notification badges. It felt like pressing Ctrl+Shift+Esc to open my brainâ€™s Task Manager and shutting down background apps of social media. Suddenly, I had so much more mental capacity freed upâ€”enough to focus on meaningful things with ease instead of circling anxiously in the same place.
My senses have become sharper. Things I never noticed before began to stand out. With my eyes off the phone screen, I was no longer a passive receiver being flooded with information, but an active, curious explorer of the world. The colors of real life became sharper, and I even became more sensitive to subtle things: the perfect humidity of the breeze brushing against my face, like the cool freshness of a face mask just applied. Drinking water no longer feels difficult. (This may relate to the second point) This is a surprising change. I usually love sweet drinks, and recently Iâ€™ve been struggling to cut down. But today, something shifted. I became more sensitive to the taste of water. Drinks that I usually had, even mildly sweetened, suddenly felt cloying. I didnâ€™t want them anymore. Instead, I began to enjoy the pure taste of water.
At the end of the day, my feeling was this: Ah! Relief! Quitting Facebook and Instagram on the first day felt like the sky finally broke into a heavy downpour after being stuffy and humid for too long. My heart was leaping with joy. I could sense that the parts of me dulled or weakened by social media were slowly, step by step, coming back to life.
posts.title: What Happened When I Deleted My Facebook and Instagram App?
